awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Time after Time: Adaptive Seasonal Timing Drives the Sequential Origin of Community Biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The timing of seasonal life cycles is a critical question underlying many biological processes, including the generation and maintenance of biodiversity and agriculture production and food security.  Animals and plants must synchronize their lives with the seasons to avoid freezing or overheating and to exploit seasonal resources. The goal of this grant is to understand how historic and contemporary shifts in seasonality can facilitate biological diversification in insect communities. In the short term, such shifts have caused rapid evolution of new crop pests and associated parasite communities. The proposed research tests 1) whether the same processes explain more ancient diversification of communities, and 2) whether changing climates will disrupt or promote diversification in the future. The results may inform many scientific fields, from basic research on the genesis of new species to applied control of agricultural pests. This project includes workshops with high school teachers and students to build curricula supporting "learning by doing" and meeting national standards, as well as providing training for graduate students and postdocs. 

This project includes genomic analysis of dipteran pest insects, including the apple fly Rhagoletis pomonella and blueberry maggot fly Rhagoletis mendax plus the community of parasitoid wasps that attack these flies. Genomic work will integrate with 1) functional studies of the overwintering hibernation of both the flies and the wasps from hormonal and molecular perspectives, and 2) computational simulations of the responses of the flies and their parasites to projected seasonal shifts resulting from climate change.

por.por_cntn:
Many insects spend the cold months of winter in a semi-dormant state called diapause. Insects subsequently time when they break diapause and develop into adults to correspond with when the food resources they depend on, such as plant leaves and fruit, become available for feedng. This is especially true for fruit flies in the genus Rhagoletis that only have one generation a year, mate on and lay their eggs only into ripe fruit that is still on the vine on their specific host plants, and only live for at most a month in nature. As a result, different Rhagoletis flies that use different host plants whose fruit ripen at different times of the year are reproductively isolated from one another by the differences in when they break diapause and are sexually active as adults. Thus, shifts in the flies between plants with differnt fruitng times can start the speciation process.

The goal of this Dimensions of Biodiversity grant was to examine the genetic basis for the differences in two Rhagoletis flies that attack hawthorns, the original host that fruits later in September, and the new host domesticated apple that fruits earlier in August. In addition, we examined how these differences in host plant fruiting time translate through the Rhagoletis flies to affect the diapause timing of the parasitic wasps that attack the flies. Like the flies, these wasps have one generation a year and an even shorter lifespan of two weeks than the flies. Thus, the flies and wasps are engaged in an ecological and evolutionary game of hide and seek in which, by shifting to a new host plant that fruits at a different time, the fly escapes parasitism from the wasps and diversifies. However, eventually the wasp catches up and shifts its diapause timing too and, in the process, forms new races and species of wasps. We call this sequential speciation because a shift in the lower fly trophic level of the ecosystem has sequential effects that cause shifts in the higher trophic level of wasps that parasitize the flies.

Our results supported the sequential speciation hypothesis and provided insight into the genetic basis of diapause termination differences between hawthorn and apple attacking Rhagoletis flies. Specifically we found that many genes are involved, that they tend to become more active in being turned on as winter progresses in apple comapred to hawthorn flies (consistent with apple flies breaking diapause earlier to attack the earlier fruiting apple), and that many of these genes reside on three chromosomes in the genome of the fly that possess inversions (chunks of chromosomes where the order of genes they contain are reversed relative to one another and act as blocks whose component genes are not readily interchanged). We also characterized the timing of the diapause differences between apple and hawthorn-fly attacking wasps and showed that they differ just like the flies, and we are currently in the process of determining the genetic basis for these differences to see if they are like those of the flies and involve many genes in inversions or not.

In addition to the basic science implications of our study for determining how diapause works and the sequential effects of how differences in diapause timing translates into new biodiversity for insects through the ecosystem, our results are also of applied interest. Many species of Rhagoletis flies are economic pests of commercially important fruit crops, including not only apples but blueberries, cherries, and walnuts, as well. Thus, understanding how diapause works can also provide insight into new ways to control these pest flies.

The research conducted for the Dimensions grant helped train eight graduate students and 19 undergraduate students in the Feder lab at the University of Notre Dame and resulted in 39 publications in peer-reviewed journals, as well as several additional papers in press and currently in review.
